questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being punched in the right side of his face. His plain radiograph is shown below. Which of the following bones maximally contributes to the region fractured?
questions.solution:
The plain radiograph shows a fracture of the floor of the orbit. The maximum contribution to the floor of the orbit is by the maxilla.

Boundaries of the bony orbit:

  • Roof: 
    • The orbital plate of the frontal bone 
    • Sphenoid bone (small part)
  • Floor: Thin plate of bone that also forms the roof of the maxillary sinus
    • The orbital plate of the maxilla
    • Zygomatic bone (anterolateral)
    • Orbital process of palatine bone (posteromedial)
  • Medial wall:
    • Maxilla
    • Lacrimal bone
    • Ethmoid bone
    • Sphenoid bone
  • Lateral wall: 
    • Zygomatic bone (anterior)
    • Greater wing of sphenoid (posterior)
    • Sphenozygomatic suture.

The orbital floor can be fractured by trauma to the orbit as seen in falls, motor vehicle accidents, and assaults. The image given shows X-ray Water's view with a 'teardrop' sign. The orbital contents leak out of the fractured orbital floor, giving it a teardrop-like appearance.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with complaints of shortness of breath and tiredness. There is no history of reactive airway disease or heart diseases previously. She has a history of breast cancer for which breast conservation surgery and chemoradiation were done. On examination, there were engorged neck veins and JVP showed rapid x and y descent and Chest Xray is as below.Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the JVP findings of rapid X and Y descent  are suggestive of constrictive pericarditis.

Constrictive pericarditis:

  • It is the condition where a thickened, fibrotic, and often calcified pericardium restricts the diastolic filling of the heart.
  • In developing countries, infectious etiologies like tuberculosis or viral infections are the most common cause of this condition.
  • Cardiac surgery and radiation therapy are also common causes.
  • Other causes include connective tissue disease, uremia, neoplasm, or idiopathic.
  • Clinically the patients present with dyspnea, orthopnea, and fatigue.
  • JVP findings - There is a rapid 'x' and 'y' descent. The rapid 'y' descent is more prominent and reflects rapid early ventricular diastolic filling. This occurs due to the constricting pericardium, increasing the atrial pressures.

Diagnosis:

  • Diagnosis is difficult and is confirmed by multiple investigations
  • Hallmark findings of pericardial constriction are pericardial thickening, calcification, and abnormal ventricular diastolic function.
  • The X-ray can be normal or there may be non-specific cardiac enlargement, calcification, and roughened cardiac outline.
  • Echo can assess the hemodynamic function but it is accurate in identifying pericardial thickening.
  • CT and MRI are more sensitive investigations.
  • CT has an edge over MRI as it can detect calcification associated with this condition.
  • Pericardial thickness of > 4mm along with clinical features of constriction is highly suggestive of this diagnosis.
  • Cardiac MR may show diastolic septal bounce.
  • Hepatomegaly and ascites can be seen associated with this condition.

Constrictive pericarditis will have prominent y descent, prominent x descent, and Kussmaul's sign. Normally, the venous pressure should fall by at least 3 mmHg with inspiration. Kussmaul’s sign is defined by either a rise or a lack of fall of the JVP with inspiration.

Other important conditions and their JVP tracings are

  • In Cardiac tamponade, the jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing of the patient will have a prominent x descent but an absent y descent.
  • Atrioventricular block will have cannon a waves
  • Atrial fibrillation will have absent a wave
  • Tricuspid regurgitation will have accentuated v wave with rapid y descent
  • Tricuspid stenosis will have prolonged y wave

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: The patient presents with pigmentation of the face as shown in the image below and gradually increasing backache and stiffness. The X-ray image of the spine is shown. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical image shows the accumulation of alkapton bodies in connective tissues on the face, a characteristic feature of alkaptonuria, while the X-ray reveals calcification of intervertebral discs, known as ochronotic spondyloarthropathy, which is also associated with alkaptonuria.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase/ homogentisic acid 1, 2 - dioxygenase, which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate. The defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of homogentisate, which is then excreted in the urine.

Alkaptonuria is characterized by homogentisic aciduria, ochronosis, and arthropathy (joint pain).

Homogentisic aciduria is the black discolouration of urine on prolonged exposure to air caused due to oxidation of the excreted homogentisate. Ochronosis, which is bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissue; generally occurs after the third decade of life and it occurs due to the accumulation of homogentisic acid and its oxidation products like benzoquinone acetic acid in connective tissue.

Diagnosis: Blackish discoloration of urine on standing is diagnostic of alkaptonuria (shown below). The ferric chloride test will be positive.

Other options:

Option A: Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a genetic disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to the accumulation of phenylalanine in the blood. Clinical features include intellectual disability, seizures, eczema, and a distinctive musty odour in the urine.

Option C: Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is a rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency in the branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase complex, impairing the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids. Clinical features include vomiting, poor feeding, lethargy, and the characteristic maple syrup odour in the urine.

Option D: Tyrosinemia is a genetic disorder caused by defects in the enzymes involved in the metabolism of tyrosine, leading to its accumulation in the body. Clinical features include liver dysfunction, renal tubular disease, rickets, and in severe cases, neurological deterioration.

Related Pearl: Metabolism of phenylalanine and tyrosine

Related Pearl: Amino acid Enzymatic Disorders and the Associated Enzymes

Disorder

Enzyme defect

Phenylketonuria

Phenylalanine hydroxylase

Tyrosinosis (Tyrosinemia type I)

Maleyl Acetate isomerase or Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase

Maple syrup urine disease 

Branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase(BCKAD)

Alkaptonuria

Homogentisate oxidase

Albinism

Tyrosinase

Homocystinuria type I

Cystathionine synthase

Homocystinuria type II

Defect in methylcobalamin formation

Cystathioninuria

Cystathionase

Tyrosinemia type II or Richner-Hanhart syndrome

Tyrosine transaminase or Tyrosine aminotransferase

Primary hyperoxaluria

Alanine glyoxalate aminotransferase

Hypervalinemia

Valine transaminase

Isovaleric acidemia

Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase

Histidinemia

Histidase

Hyperprolinemia type I

Proline oxidase

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with hemoptysis, red-colored urine, and frequent sinusitis. Her blood reports revealed anemia, leucocytosis, and elevated ESR. Serology is positive for antiproteinase-3 ANCA. Her chest X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray showing cavitating lesions in the right lung, along with positivity for antiproteinase-3 ANCA ( i.e, c-ANCA) suggests that the most likely diagnosis is granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) a.k.a Wegener's granulomatosis.

Wegener's granulomatosis is a type of vasculitis characterized by necrotizing granulomas in the upper, and lower respiratory tract, and small and medium vessels.

Clinically, they present with fever, purulent rhinorrhoea, nasal ulcers, sinus pain, polyarthralgia, cough, hemoptysis, breathlessness, hematuria, and proteinuria. Occasionally, cutaneous purpura and mononeuritis complex may be present. Necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis can be seen in the condition.

Lab investigations will show anemia, leucocytosis, elevated ESR, and high titers of cytoplasmic ANCA (c-ANCA) targetted against anti-proteinase-3 (anti-PR-3). The specificity of a positive PR-3 ANCA for Wegener's is very high, especially in the presence of active glomerulonephritis. Chest radiograph will show multiple, bilateral cavitating nodules and pulmonary infiltrates. 

The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis on biopsy.

 

Related Pearl: ANCA Antibodies

The antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are the antibodies that are targeted against the specific proteins present in neutrophils and monocytes. They can be further classified as:

 

Cytoplasmic ANCA (cANCA)

 Perinuclear ANCA (pANCA)

Directed against

Proteinase 3

 Myeloperoxidase

Predominantly positive in

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis)

Microscopic polyangiitis

Churg–Strauss syndrome 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Staining pattern

Granular cytoplasmic staining

Perinuclear or nuclear staining

Related Pearl: Important Vasculitis with Features

Vasculitis

Predominant vessel involved

Inflammatory cells

Other features

Temporal arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis)

Temporal, vertebral and ophthalmic arteries, aorta

Lymphocytes, and macrophages

>40 years old, polymyalgia rheumatica, granulomas, giant cells

Takayasu Arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis)

(Medium-sized and large arteries) Aortic arch, great vessels, pulmonary artery, coronary and renal arteries

Lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils, granulomas, giant cells

Pulseless disease

 

Polyarteritis Nodosa

Small or medium-sized muscular arteries, typically involving renal and visceral vessels

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Spares pulmonary vessels, 30% of patients with  chronic hepatitis B

Microscopic polyangiitis

Capillaries, small arterioles, venules

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Necrotizing glomerulonephritism (90% of patients) and pulmonary capillaritis leukocytoclastic vasculitis

Churg-Strauss Syndrome

Medium and small arteries

 

Eosinophils (required), lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils

Associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, lung infiltrates, peripheral hypereosinophilia, and extravascular necrotizing granulomata.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the hospital, with C/O seizures and the MRI image of the brain is given below. The disease is most probably caused by?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of seizures and the radiological findings of multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space, typical parenchymal brain calcifications are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by T. solium (Cysticercosis cellulosae).

Neurocysticercosis is the most common central nervous system parasitic infection.

The clinical features of neurocysticercosis include epilepsy, increased intracranial tension, hydrocephalus, psychiatric disturbances, meningoencephalitis, transient paresis, behavioral disorders aphasia, and visual disturbances.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with a complaint of lower backache. The radiographic image of her lumbosacral spine is given below. Her bone mineral density is measured and her  T-score is -2.8. She was given oral drugs but she was not strictly compliant with it as she was intolerant to the oral drugs. Which would be the intravenous drug useful for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given case and a T-score of -2.8 are suggestive of postmenopausal osteoporosis. Bisphosphonates (Zolindronate 5 mg intravenous annually) are used in the management of postmenopausal osteoporosis, not tolerant to oral drugs.

The above image depicts the ballooning of disc spaces leading to the biconcave shape of the vertebral body known as ‘Codfish appearance’, classically seen in osteoporosis. 

Bisphosphonates are analogs of pyrophosphate. They specifically inhibit bone resorption and thus are very effective for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis.

Mechanism of action:

Bisphosphonates concentrate at sites of active remodeling. They remain in the matrix until the bone is remodeled. Then, they are released in the acid environment of the resorption lacunae and induce apoptosis in osteoclasts.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with a history of a gunshot wound sustained while on a hunting trip. X-ray findings are as given below. Which of the following weapons is most likely to produce this type of injury?
questions.solution:
The radiograph is suggestive of a close-range shotgun blast injury to the knee. Birdshot pellets are visible within and around the shattered patella, distal femur, and proximal tibia.

The ammunition for the shotgun is a cartridge made of a cardboard or plastic cylinder fitted into a metal base. The base carries a percussion detonator that is struck by the spring-loaded firing pin when the trigger is pulled.  The primer is located in the percussion cup and contains the detonator.  The cartridge contains a charge of propellant (gunpowder), above which are ‘wads’ or pistons of felt, and cardboard or plastic discs, or both. Above these is the charge of shot (pellets), which varies greatly in number and size, finally covered by a card or plastic disc.

 

The image given below shows the entry wound in the case of a shotgun. There is a central round hole, with multiple pellet holes scattered around the central hole. This wound is most likely to have been caused by a shotgun from a range of 1-5 m.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the signs and symptoms of the condition represented below?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows enlarged adenoids and suggests the diagnosis of adenoid hypertrophy. Patients show an absent nasolabial fold.

Clinical features:

  • Nasal obstruction is the most common symptom. This leads to mouth breathing. Nasal obstruction also interferes with feeding or suckling in a child. As respiration and feeding cannot take place simultaneously, a child with adenoid enlargement fails to thrive.
  • Nasal discharge, sinusitis, and epistaxis.
  • Bilateral conductive hearing loss and serous otitis media due to eustachian tube obstruction.
  • Rhinolalia clausa - hyponasal voice.
  • Adenoid facies - elongated face with a dull expression, pinched up nose, absent nasolabial crease, open mouth, prominent and crowded upper teeth.
  • Sleep apnoea - chronic cases lead to hypoxemia and pulmonary vasoconstriction. This consequently leads to pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale.
  • Aprosexia - lack of concentration.

questions.text: An elderly man is being evaluated for exertional dyspnea, cough, and weight loss. His chest CT is given below. What is it suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The CT scan shows emphysematous lungs, with reduced parenchymal markings and focal areas of low attenuation. This represents the emphysematous destruction of the lung, indicative of hyperinflation.

Radiographic studies in COPD show:

  • Emphysematous bullae
  • A paucity of parenchymal markings
  • Hyperlucency suggests the presence of emphysema
  • Increased lung volumes and flattening of the diaphragm suggest hyperinflation

Option B: Atypical pneumonia shows patchy bilateral ground-glass opacities.

Option C: Calcified granulomas are seen as dense, bright nodules.

Option D: Interstitial fibrosis shows a honeycomb pattern of the lung parenchyma as shown below.

questions.text: Identify the imaging procedure shown below.
questions.solution:
The imaging procedure shown above is mediolateral oblique mammography.

The mammogram is an X-ray picture of the breast. The anode in the X-ray tube is made up of molybdenum. The X-ray film used is single-sided coated films.

Views used are:

  • Craniocaudal
  • Mediolateral oblique

The father of mammography is Robert Egan.

Uses of the mammogram:

  • Routine screening for DCIS.
  • The most important sign of malignancy in mammogram is clustered micro calcification (more than 5 particles in 1 cm², 3 particles of less than 0.5 mm size)

The image below shows different types of calcifications.

The image below shows MRI scans.

The image below shows a CT scan.

The image below shows a USG.

questions.text: A 3-month-old male child was brought with a history of fever and respiratory distress. Suspecting pneumonia, a chest X-ray was ordered. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows pneumatoceles (air-filled cysts within lung parenchyma), which most commonly occur in pneumonia caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

Pneumonia caused by Staphylococcus may be primary or secondary (after a viral infection such as influenza).

Clinical features include high fever, abdominal pain, dyspnoea, and tachycardia. S. aureus often causes necrotizing pneumonitis that may be associated with complications like early development of empyema, pneumatocele, pyopneumothorax, and bronchopleural fistulas.

Pneumatocoele can also be caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, E. coli, group A streptococci, Klebsiella pneumoniae, etc. However, Staphylococcus aureus is most commonly implicated.

questions.text: An X-ray skull of a patient with marked hypercalcemia is shown below. Which of the following laboratory parameters is consistent with his diagnosis?

choices.text: High alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
High alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR
Normal alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
Normal alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR

questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, hypercalcemia along with the skull demonstrating typical 'punched out' lesions is characteristic of multiple myeloma. Normal alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR are consistent with multiple myeloma.

The lesions are purely osteolytic with little or no osteoblastic activity. Hence alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is normal.

The most common site of lytic lesion in multiple myeloma is the vertebral column.

questions.text: The CT finding of a patient is shown below. What is the most common cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of a subdural hematoma and it most commonly results from injury to the bridging dural veins. 

Subdural hematoma refers to the haemorrhage between the dura and arachnoid mater. The image of the CT scan reveals a hyperdense crescentic lesion. Mass effect with midline displacement can also be seen.

Causes of SDH are:

  • Trauma
  • Anticoagulants
  • Antiplatelets
  • Alcohol abuse
  • Shaken baby syndrome.

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text: A 53-year-old man was admitted with a history of a cerebrovascular accident 2 days ago. The patient is drowsy with minimal response. CT finding is shown in the image below. What will be your next line of management?
questions.solution:
The patient is having a low GCS with CT showing significant edema in the middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory (at least >50%) along with a midline shift. In such cases, due to the risk of brain herniation, the patient needs to be referred for decompressive neurosurgery.

Guidelines for urgent decompression (STATE acronym):

  • Score - NIH Stroke scale (NIHSS) score > 15
  • Time <48h 
  • Age 18-60 yrs
  • Territory infarct >145 cm3 or >50% MCA territory
  • Expectations - Informed consent that surgery improves survival but the patient may have significant disability.

Medical management of brain edema and increased intracranial pressure (ICP) may not be successful when significant swelling occurs in the cerebral or cerebellar hemisphere.

Therefore, a decompressive craniectomy should be considered to relieve the mass effect of the swollen cerebral or cerebellar hemisphere on the thalamus, brainstem, and network projections to the cortex, which is manifested predominantly by decreased levels of arousal.

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hypertension

Definition

Intracranial hypertension is pressure within the cranium above normal. Normal range of ICP is 5-15mm Hg. Levels above 20-25mm Hg are usually treated. 

Causes: Intracranial haemorrhage, brain tumors, head injury, meningitis, brain abscess, etc. 

Symptoms of raised ICT

  • Cushing’s triad – hypertension, bradycardia and respiratory depression
  • Headache, visual blurring due to papilloedema and abducent nerve palsy 
  • Focal symptoms may arise due to the local effects in patients with mass lesions or due to herniation.
  • Seizures
  • Stroke

Investigations

  • CT brain or MRI brain with gadolinium to rule out ICSOL 
  • Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the presence of raised ICT due to the risk of coning.
  • Papilledema (as an indicator of ICT) should be ruled out before lumbar puncture.

Treatment

  • Dexamethasone
  • Ventriculotomy to remove CSF or ventriculoperitoneal shunt
  • Decompressive craniectomy
  • Surgical resection of ICSOL – by craniotomy or stereotactic radiosurgery
  • Whole brain radiation for multiple metastases causing raised ICT

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive man presents with fever for 3 weeks, dry cough, and significant weight loss. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture with features of atypical pneumonia and CXR showing bilateral reticulonodular infiltrates is suggestive of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia.

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is an HIV/AIDS-defining opportunistic infection. The clinical manifestations include profound weight loss, fever, dyspnea, and non-productive cough. Chest X-ray shows diffuse infiltrates beginning in the perihilar region (characteristic) and atypical manifestations include nodular lesions, cavitary lesions, etc.

questions.text: A peripherally inserted central catheter line(PICC) was placed in a patient to provide parenteral nutrition. Following the insertion, a chest X-ray was taken, which appeared as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the ideal position of the tip of this catheter?
questions.solution:
The ideal position of the tip of a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line, is superior vena cava.

Peripherally inserted central catheters are commonly used for providing parenteral nutrition therapy. They are inserted through veins in the upper arm, and guided into the central venous system, such that the tip of the catheter enters the superior vena cava. A chest X-ray is taken to confirm the position of the tip.

PICC lines have the advantage of minimizing inconvenience to the patients and clinicians. However, if the patient develops thrombophlebitis, the PICC line may be destroyed.

The image below shows (A) a typical PICC line (B) an illustration showing insertion of PICC line (C) a patient with PICC line inserted through the upper arm.

The image below shows the chest X-ray confirming the position of the tip of the PICC line (arrows), in the superior vena cava.

questions.text: An infant with Edward's syndrome presents with the following radiological finding. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Mostly presents as vomiting within 1 week
Erythromycin exposure in the first 2 weeks of life can lead to this condition
Palpation of the pyloric olive is pathognomonic  for this condition

questions.solution:
The radiographic image showing the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble (single bubble) is suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). It most commonly presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting between 2-8 weeks of age and is only rarely seen after 13 weeks.

Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. First-born male infants are at the highest risk.

Risk factors for congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis:

  • Turner syndrome
  • Edwards syndrome
  • Erythromycin or azithromycin exposure in the first 2 weeks of life either orally or via mother's milk.

Palpation of the olive-shaped mass in the epigastrium is considered pathognomonic. 

USG criteria for diagnosing hypertrophic pyloric stenosis - pyloric muscle thickness of >3-4 mm or a pyloric length >15-18 mm in the presence of functional gastric outlet obstruction is diagnostic.

questions.text: A young boy was brought to the casualty with a history of fever and abdominal pain. On examination, he was febrile,pulse rate was 104 beats/min and there was right iliac fossa tenderness.The CT scan image is shown below. Which of the following  signs is not seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
The patient is diagnosed with acute appendicitis based on the clinical presentation and a CT scan revealing an appendix measuring more than 6 mm. Ballance's sign is not associated with appendicitis but is observed in cases of a ruptured spleen.

Ballance sign is positive if there is a fixed dullness to percussion in the left flank and shifting dullness to percussion in the right flank. The fixed dullness is  due to the presence of coagulated blood near the lacerated spleen while the shifting dullness is due to the presence of blood in the peritoneal cavity.

CT signs of appendicitis include an appendix measuring greater than 6 mm in diameter, appendicolith and enhancement of its wall with intravenous contrast medium  Surrounding inflammatory changes include increased fat attenuation, fluid, phlegmon, caecal thickening, abscess and extraluminal gas.

Other options:

Option A: Aaron sign is pain or pressure in epigastrium or anterior chest with persistent firm pressure applied to Mcburney point.

Option B: Rovsing sign is seen in appendicitis. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa may cause pain in the right iliac fossa.

Option C: The Psoas sign is seen in appendicitis. Occasionally, an inﬂamed appendix lies on the psoas muscle, and the patient, often a young adult, will lie with the right hip ﬂexed, for pain relief.

Note: CT axial cuts are viewed from below to top and thus appendix is on the left of the CT image.

Related Pearl: Signs in appendicitis

Sign

Characteristic

Seen in

Dunphy’s sign

Pain on coughing

Acute appendicitis

Rovsing sign

 

Pain in the right lower quadrant during palpation of the left lower quadrant

Acute appendicitis

Obturator sign

Pain on internal rotation of hip

Pelvic appendicitis

Ilio-Psoas sign

Pain on extension of hip

Retrocaecal appendicitis

Aaron sign

Pain or pressure in epigastrium or anterior chest with persistent firm pressure applied to McBurney’s point

Acute appendicitis

Basseler sign

Sharp pain created by compressing appendix between abdominal wall and iliacus

Chronic appendicitis

Blumberg’s sign

Transient abdominal wall rebound tenderness

Peritoneal inflammation

Ten Horn sign

 Pain caused by gentle traction of right testicle

Appendicitis

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is incidentally found to have a lesion in the right lobe of the liver during an abdominal ultrasound. CECT showed the presence of a well-defined hypodense lesion with asymmetrical nodular peripheral enhancement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CECT abdomen showing a well-defined hypodense lesion in the liver with asymmetrical nodular peripheral enhancement is characteristic of hemangioma.

Hemangioma is a benign tumor composed of increased proliferation of blood vessels. It is the most common benign tumor of the liver and is mainly seen in women at a mean age of 45 years.

Small capillary hemangiomas are of no clinical significance. They are usually solitary, <5 cm in diameter, with equal occurrence in the right and left halves of the liver. However, giant hemangiomas of diameter >5 cm require attention. 

They are most commonly asymptomatic and incidentally found in imaging studies. Large compressive masses may cause vague upper abdominal symptoms. The appearance of hepatic hemangioma in a contrast-enhanced CT scan is as follows:

  • Non-contrast phase: Well-defined hypodense lesion
  • Arterial phase: Peripheral nodular enhancement
  • Washout phase: Homogenous enhancement.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with post-menopausal bleeding. Ultrasonography revealed a mass with feeding vessel as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Visualisation of a feeding vessel on ultrasonography is characteristic of an endometrial polyp.

Ultrasonography shows endometrial polyps, which are homogeneous, isoechoic to and continuous with the endometrium and preserve the endomyometrial interface. They may be centrally cystic, corresponding to dilated, fluid-filled glands. Colour Doppler usually reveals a characteristic feeding vessel.

 Benign endometrial polyps commonly occur at all ages, with their greatest prevalence after age 50. They are a common cause of postmenopausal bleeding.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents to the OG clinic with complaints of lower abdominal pain and mild bleeding per vaginum for 2 days at 12 weeks of gestation.  She also complains of excessive vomiting for one week. USG was done and it is given below.  What is the probable diagnosis____
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture along with the image is suggestive of complete mole.  The USG image shows the characteristic “snowstorm” appearance seen in complete mole. Notably, a fetus and amnionic sac are absent. 

Molar pregnancy may present with bleeding per vaginum or an acute discharge of vesicular mass per vaginum. On examination, the uterine size is more than the corresponding period of amenorrhea. It shows a characteristic snowstorm appearance on USG.  

Suction and evacuation is the treatment of choice. Here post evacuation, Intrauterine devices are not recommended during the period of surveillance. This is because there is increased risk of perforation during this period if an invasive mole is present.

Post-evacuation recommendations:

  • Anti-D immune globulin if Rh D-negative
  • Initiate effective contraception (IUD contraindicated)
  • Review pathology report
  • Serum hCG levels: within 48 h of evacuation, weekly until undetectable, then monthly for 6 months.

Pregnancy is allowed after 6 months following a negative hCG titer.

Snowstorms in radiology:

  • Complete hydatiform mole (ultrasound)
  • Extracapsular breast implant rupture (ultrasound)
  • Thyroid pulmonary metastases (chest radiograph)

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XXX or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman conceived after being treated for infertility. Her USG scan is given below. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the twin peak sign which is seen in dichorionic diamniotic twins. This is also known as the lambda sign or delta sign.

In dichorionic twins, the intervening membrane between the twins has 4 layers i.e. 2 chorions and 2 amnions. The placenta protrudes from the base to the space between the 2 amnion layers. This gives rise to the twin peak sign i.e. triangle with the base at placenta and apex in the intervening membrane.

The lambda sign: 

Sonographic assessment of dichorionicity is done by observing the following:

  • Number of placental masses - 2
  • Presence of intervening membrane - twin peak or lambda or delta sign
  • Thickness of intervening membranes ≥ 2mm

The best time of delivery of dichorionic diamniotic twins is 38 weeks.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones (indicated by the arrow in the image below) giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A term baby born after a prolonged labour presented with respiratory distress. X-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The above baby with respiratory distress has X-ray findings of hyperinflation and coarse streaking, suggestive of meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS).

MAS is seen in term and post-term babies. Blockade of large and small airways by the aspirated meconium causes atelectasis and emphysema. Complications include pneumothorax, persistant pulmonary hypertension and respiratory failure.

Radiological findings in Meconium aspiration syndrome:

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a patient presenting with a bone tumor showing a sunburst appearance on imaging?
questions.solution:
A bone tumor with a sunburst appearance on imaging is most likely osteosarcoma.

Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the commonly involved sites.

In osteosarcoma, the tumor lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on X-ray.

Other options:

Option A: Osteoclastoma or Giant cell tumor is commonly seen in the age group of 20-40 years with a slight female preponderance. The distal end of the femur is the most common location followed by the proximal tibia and distal radius. 

Radiographic findings: 

  • Eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Soap bubble appearance
  • Periosteal new bone formation is absent.

Option B: Osteoid Osteoma

The image shows presence of metadiaphyseal cortical osteoid osteoma involving the upper end of the femur with radiolucent nidus surrounded by cortical sclerosis.

Nidus of osteoid osteoma is present in the cortex and hence CT scan will be the best investigation to diagnose osteoid osteoma.

Image:

  • Black arrow - Nidus
  • White arrow - Cortical sclerosis

Option D: Ewing's sarcoma is a primary malignant tumor of the bone commonly involving the age group of 4-25 years involving the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus.

X-ray shows onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is the typical finding.

Related Pearl: Summary of Bone Tumors

questions.text: A child with recurrent UTIs is suspected to have a congenital renal anomaly. The following picture is seen on IV urography. Based on these findings, which of the following would you suspect?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a right-sided fish hook or S-shaped ureter. It describes the appearance of a retrocaval ureter as the right ureter hooks behind the IVC.

Circumcaval or retrocaval ureter is a developmental anomaly of the inferior vena cava (IVC). It is due to abnormal development of the right supracardinal system. There is a persistent right posterior cardinal vein that ends up passing in front of the ureter. The anomaly always occurs on the right side, as this is the side of the normal IVC.

Note: Bilateral fishhook or J-shaped or hockey stick ureters describe the course of the distal ureter in patients with significant benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH).

questions.text: A smoker who was given an interscalene block for an arthroscopic acromioclavicular joint reconstruction 2 days ago was followed up by a Chest x-ray which showed as below. He is asymptomatic at present and is comfortably resting on the bed. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Insert chest drain as soon as possible
Wait and watch and give supplementary oxygen if needed

questions.solution:
The next step of management is to wait and watch and give oxygen if needed. This is a case of postoperative asymptomatic pneumothorax.

As the patient is asymptomatic with no symptoms of dyspnoea or respiratory distress the best way to manage is to wait and watch. 

Postoperative pneumothorax is seen mostly in patients with pre existing lung conditions like asthma or in chronic smokers. The pre-existing blebs or bullae in the individuals rupture due to pressure gradients created by the positive pressure from ventilation or the arthroscopic pump and shaver system used during surgery.

The pressure gradient from the positive pressure of anesthesia and the ipsilateral lung is highest in the lateral decubitus position.

The other complications that can occur are subcutaneous emphysema, pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked as A in the CT scan shown below:
questions.solution: The structure marked as "A" in the CT Thorax is the ascending aorta.

questions.text: Pick out the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The given Xray shows Cervical rib.

Patients with a cervical rib usually show a lump and tenderness in the supraclavicular fossa.

The pallor and paresthesias are due to vascular and neural compressions each respectively.

Radiogram of the neck is useful in detecting a cervical rib.

However, the absence of a rib on the x-ray does not rule out the possibility of a cervical rib. CT and MRI are more sensitive.

questions.text: The characteristic appearance of esophagus on barium swallow, given below,  is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The corkscrew appearance or rosary bead appearance of the esophagus is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm.

Diffuse esophageal spasm is a hypermotility disorder of the esophagus seen more commonly in women. Patients usually present with dysphagia and chest pain which is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the oesophageal body. However, in between the contractions, peristalsis remains normal.

Pathologically, there is marked hypertrophy of the circular muscles and the barium swallow study shows a corkscrew appearance or rosary bead appearance.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: Identify the rib highlighted in the X-ray.
questions.solution:
The above-marked area in the chest X-ray shows the posterior part of the 4th rib.

In the chest X-ray, ribs appear as light grey strips. The anterior part of the rib is more oblique and the medial part cannot be demonstrable as it ends with costal cartilage. The posterior part of the rib is more horizontal and the attachment of the rib with the vertebra can be easily made out.

 

The anterior(yellow) and posterior(red) ribs are highlighted in the image given below.
